Problem:
Consider a complex function \\( z(t) = x(t) + iy(t) \\) being transformed via a Fourier Transform \\( F(z)(\\omega) \\), yielding a frequency domain representation. Analyze the impact of a differential operator \\( D \\) defined as \\( D = \\frac{d}{dt} \\) on the original time-domain signal.

If an intervention occurs where an additional function \\( h(t) \\) is added to \\( z(t) \\) at a time \\( t_1 \\), will the final Fourier Transform be a simple addition of the Fourier Transforms of \\( z(t) \\) and \\( h(t) \\)?
Explanation: The Fourier Transform of the sum of two functions is the sum of their Fourier Transforms (linearity of the Fourier Transform). Hence, adding \\( h(t) \\) to \\( z(t) \\) at \\( t_1 \\) and then transforming the result will simply add the Fourier Transform of \\( h(t) \\) to that of \\( z(t) \\).
